body: THE best of the casual restaurants reviewed this year proved that delicious doesn't have to mean expensive. AYADA This is a serious Thai restaurant that makes no concessions to Western palates. The menu is encyclopedic; the waitresses are patient. Put yourself in the gentle but firm hands of the chef and owner, Duangjai Thammasat (known as Kitty),
title: Breaking the Mold, Not the Bank

body: About two years ago, Debra Salomon was on her way to the new Fairway market in Red Hook, Brooklyn, when she took a wrong turn and found herself on a windblown pier that had two 90-foot Eiffel-like towers rising into the sky for no apparent purpose. Ms. Salomon quickly saw a purpose. She is a designer and teaches design at the City University of New
title: RED HOOK JOURNAL; 2 Idle Towers May Test the Wind's Power to Keep a Bit of Brooklyn Moving

body: The authorities came early on Tuesday, entering the six-story apartment building on Brighton 12th Street in the heart of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. They headed upstairs, stopping at the fourth-floor apartment where Tatyana and Abram Grinman lived. The Grinmans, especially Tatyana, were known in the building; neighbors said she had approached many of
title: In Brighton Beach, Clues to Holocaust Case

body: While fleeing the Nazis in 1941, an 11-year-old girl dodged airplane bombs as she crossed the Dnieper River in Ukraine, ultimately finding refuge in Donetsk, where she and her mother lived in hiding until the liberation of 1944. A 13-year-old boy escaped from Kiev with his mother and younger sister, shuttling from basements to barns and sometimes
title: Workers at Holocaust Fund Face Fraud Charges

body: The Sunday shoppers at the St. Petersburg Trade and Publishing House hardly noticed the remarkably tall man flipping through compact discs. The old men playing cards by the boardwalk never looked up. It was only when the tall man, shadowed by a small television crew, approached the basketball court at Brighton Playground in Brooklyn that someone
title: Big Man in Little Odessa

body: ON THE SCREEN At first glance, Advanced Style looks like an ordinary street-fashion photo blog. The mostly vertical images of pedestrians in dapper suits and fanciful skirts mingle with short descriptions of the clothing and back stories about the wearers. But the models are unlike those featured in Vogue or on Style.com. They are older. Much
title: CITY ROOM; NEW YORK ONLINE: Where to Point Your Browser

body: THE city as poem, art piece, happening, living theater: New Yorkers have all experienced their own versions, and the leaders of the conceptual walks that make up Elastic City want to create new ones. What is a conceptual walking tour? Todd Shalom, Elastic City's founder and director, said he was ''still shaping the vocabulary.'' But on a recent
title: Where the Sidewalks End, And the City (Really) Begins

body: Mother Russia has long been ensconced in Brooklyn's Brighton Beach, feasting on pirogi, borscht and the tang of salty air reminiscent of Odessa. But her assimilated children have been planting colonies across the New York area, and one of the largest is flourishing on Staten Island. Staten Island's Russians -- even if many are really from Ukraine
title: STATEN ISLAND JOURNAL; As Russians Move In and Flourish, Resentment Follows

body: A-WAH 5 Catherine Street (East Broadway), (212) 925-8308. Bo zai fan -- loosely, ''clay pot rice'' in Cantonese -- is the specialty, but it's easy to miss on the 300-item menu. Look for ''world famous rice in casserole.'' At A-Wah, which the chef and owner, Wang Jian Wah, opened in March, this Hong Kong comfort food is served in 17 varieties. Each
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: THOSE of us among the living all know New York City can be maddeningly expensive, whether one is shopping for a $40 million mansion on Fifth Avenue or a $2,500 studio walk-up in a former tenement on the Lower East Side. For the dead, however, virtually no amount of money will secure a final resting place in the heart of a city that is fast running
title: GRAVEYARD GRIDLOCK

body: I HAD the route mapped out in my mind. I would bike from the Lower East Side of Manhattan, hit the taco trucks along the ball fields of Red Hook, Brooklyn, cruise through Prospect Park over to Brighton Beach for a quick dip, then hypotenuse it back to a bar in Williamsburg to watch the World Cup finals. Out of curiosity, I consulted Google Maps's
title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; Google Leads, You Pedal

body: A group of day care center operators bribed workers at three New York City agencies and exploited the complex social service bureaucracy to loot millions of dollars from a program that pays child-care expenses for poor parents so they can find work, officials said Tuesday. Federal prosecutors called it a ''massive fraud and bribery scheme''
title: Day Care Operators Are Accused of Bilking City Program for Working Poor

body: Aretha Franklin has canceled two free concerts in Brooklyn next week because of an injury suffered on Sunday. The shows -- at Wingate Field in East Flatbush on Monday, and Asser Levy Park in Brighton Beach on Aug. 12 -- were part of two series presented by Marty Markowitz, the borough president, and were to be the first concerts by Ms. Franklin,
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Aretha Franklin Cancels Free Concerts In Brooklyn

body: Brooklyn and Queens are on the same island, which means Wally Backman can feel the tremors from out east. The Mets, his old team, are having a stinker of a season -- another stinker, that is to say -- but Backman's current team, the Cyclones, is winning two-thirds of its games. title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Backman Is Poised On Top Step of the Dugout

title: $25 AND UNDER; Korean Via An Uzbek Sojourn

body: ATLANTIC BEACH, N.Y. title: SUMMER RITUALS | MAH-JONGG; At These Cabanas, 'The Tiles That Bind'

title: CITY ROOM; Bronx Is Up? Innate Sense May Tell Us

title: On TV, Chicago (in New York) Is Stage Actors' New Refuge

title: 'Thank You for Calling 311

body: ALONG the East and Hudson Rivers, on stretches of Jamaica Bay, and by the banks of the Gowanus Canal, formerly neglected industrial land has recently been reborn as parkland, or will be before long. title: LIVING IN | BRIGHTON BEACH, BROOKLYN; Views to Fill the Eye, Not Empty the Wallet

title: Now Onstage, Spaces to Lust For

body: DEAR DIARY: The wind and rain were howling on that Saturday in March. My 95-year-old mother and I were planning to see the Paul Taylor Dance Company at City Center. She was being driven in from Connecticut, so I left my house in Brooklyn, walked to Kings Highway and waited for the bus to the Q train. I was buffeted by wind and rain. No bus to be
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: Success always breeds imitation. On television, there are three varieties of ''CSI,'' three of ''Law & Order,'' and at least four of ''Real Housewives.'' But in the case of MTV's ''Jersey Shore,'' the original network is not the one doing the imitating. That did not stop some people from jumping to conclusions when casting calls for hard-partying
title: 'Jersey Shore' Spawns Clear Imitations, but Not From MTV

body: A 2-year-old Brooklyn boy was left on a school bus for two hours on Tuesday after the driver and the bus matron forgot to drop him off at day care, then went to their homes for a break, the police said. Officers found the child in the bus, parked outside the driver's Brighton Beach home, about 10:30 a.m. after a passer-by heard the boy crying and
title: Boy, 2, Left on School Bus for Two Hours

body: Anastasia Kurinnaya, shod in a pair of black Aldo booties with five-inch heels, stepped carefully down the 10 rickety plywood stairs that led from the coat check into the grimy basement of Passion, a popular Russian dance club on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn. She signed the release form handed to her by a guy with a clipboard and walked inside
title: A Russian 'Jersey Shore'? This Crowd Is Hopeful

title: EXPLORER; Israel With a Russian Accent (and Pork)

body: The way Marty Markowitz sees it, the rundown nine-acre park where Coney Island and Brighton Beach meet is ripe for a sparkling transformation. Mr. Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, envisions Asser Levy Park, also known as Seaside Park, as the gateway to a spruced-up amusement complex evoking Coney Island's splashy past. title: Clash Over Plans for a Brooklyn Park

body: Three years ago, Robert Ivker, a radiation oncologist, read an article about a caseworker dedicated to helping Holocaust survivors apply for reparations from the German government. The article, part of the Neediest Cases campaign, inspired him to start a fund to benefit New York-area Holocaust survivors, many of whom were destitute. His own efforts
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Inspired to Pick Up Where Others Left Off For Holocaust Survivors

body: In accordance with the old Julian calendar, the Russian Orthodox Church celebrates Christmas on Jan. 7. So on Christmas Eve, about three weeks ago, the reunited Shevchenko family -- who immigrated from Ukraine to Albany in 2007 -- had reason to celebrate the relief and security of a new, clean and bedbug-free apartment in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Facing Lean Times, but Together Again, in a New Home for the Holiday

body: From 2006 to 2008, the deadliest roads for pedestrians in the city were Third Avenue in Manhattan and Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, which each had nine fatalities, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Along Third Avenue, which is six-and-a-half miles long and runs from Cooper Square to 129th Street, East Harlem
title: Third and Atlantic Avenues Have Most Fatalities

body: Ruth Usherenko keeps an improbably thick book on a table beside the couch in her living room. In it are roughly 58,000 names, all belonging to Jewish Berliners who perished during Hitler's regime. ''All my girlfriends, all my relatives, all my neighbors are in here,'' Ms. Usherenko, 79, said of the macabre encyclopedia, which the German government
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Surviving the Camps but Struggling in Brooklyn
